questions.text: Renal osteodystrophy differs nutritional and genetic forms of osteomalacia in having:
Anaemia of advanced renal insufficiency is best treated by:
The most specific marker of renal functionis:
Acute kidney injury can be differentiated from CKI by which of the following:
questions.correct_answer: D. Preserved CMD on USG scan
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation for Incorrect Answers:
  • • A. An increased urinary Na + : Increased urinary sodium excretion may be seen in AKI, particularly in intrinsic renal causes like acute tubular necrosis (ATN). However, urinary sodium levels are not specific to differentiate between AKI and CKD since sodium handling may also be impaired in advanced CKD.
  • • B. LVH on ECG: Left ventricular hypertrophy (LVH) on ECG is commonly associated with long-standing hypertension or volume overload, conditions frequently seen in CKD due to prolonged renal dysfunction. It is not specific for distinguishing between AKI and CKD, as it reflects chronic cardiovascular changes rather than acute kidney injury.
  • • C. Hypophosphatemia: Hypophosphatemia is not a typical finding in either AKI or CKD. Instead, hyperphosphatemia is often seen in CKD due to impaired phosphate excretion. Phosphorus levels can also increase in AKI, particularly in intrinsic renal causes, making this option irrelevant for differentiation.

questions.text: A young man develops gross hematuria 3 days after an attack of URTI. Most likely renal pathology is:

options.label: A
options.text: The pathologic changes are proliferation and usually confined to mesangial cells usually focal and segmental.

options.text: Hematuria may be gross or microscopic.

options.label: C
options.text: On immune-fluroescence deposits contain both IgA and IgG maybe found.

options.label: D
options.text: Absence of associated proteinuria is pathognomonic

questions.correct_answer: D. Absence of associated proteinuria is pathognomonic

options.label: A
options.text: The latent period appears to be longer when PSGN is associated with cutaneous rather than pharyngeal infections

options.label: B
options.text: Penicillin therapy is without value once renal disease is established

options.label: C
options.text: Long-term antistreptococcal prophylaxis is indicated after a prior documented case of PSGN

questions.correct_answer: C. Long-term antistreptococcal prophylaxis is indicated after a prior documented case of PSGN

questions.text: All of the following statements regarding analgesic nephropathy are true EXCEPT:

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: Anemia, hematuria and proteinuria are common

options.label: C
options.text: Occurs with high dose, long-term use & combinations

options.label: D
options.text: More often in elderly, DM, HTN, rheumatic diseases.

questions.correct_answer: B. Anemia, hematuria and proteinuria are common

questions.text: Peritoneal Dialysis has following complications except:
A 40-year-old male with chronic kidney disease who weighs 70kg, has a serum creatinine value of 1.4mg/dl. What is the stage of his CKD:
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Stage 1: GFR ≥ 90 mL/min/1.73m² (with other evidence of kidney damage, such as proteinuria). Stage 2: GFR 60-89 mL/min/1.73m² (with kidney damage). Stage 3: GFR 30-59 mL/min/1.73m². Stage 4: GFR 15-29 mL/min/1.73m². Stage 5: GFR < 15 mL/min/1.73m² (or dialysis). In this case, the patient's serum creatinine is 1.4 mg/dL. Given that this serum creatinine level is not extremely high, we can estimate that the patient's GFR likely falls in the range of 60-89 mL/min/1.73m², which corresponds to Stage 2 CKD. This stage indicates mild kidney dysfunction, where kidney damage is present but the GFR is still relatively preserved.
  • • Explanation for Incorrect Answers:
  • • A. Stage 1: Stage 1 CKD requires a GFR ≥ 90 mL/min/1.73m², but the patient’s serum creatinine value suggests a GFR lower than this threshold. Therefore, Stage 1 is not applicable.
  • • C. Stage 3: Stage 3 CKD corresponds to a GFR of 30-59 mL/min/1.73m². Given the serum creatinine level of 1.4 mg/dL, the patient's GFR is likely above this range, making Stage 3 unlikely.
  • • D. Stage 4: Stage 4 CKD requires a GFR of 15-29 mL/min/1.73m², which is much lower than what would be expected with a serum creatinine of 1.4 mg/dL. Stage 4 is unlikely based on this information.
